The Hong Kong Palace Museum presents over 900 cultural treasures from the Palace Museum, some of which have never been shown to the public before. These gems of Chinese culture are curated into nine thematic exhibitions. To complete this new cultural destination, the Museum is also home to multimedia installations, learning programmes and cultural activities. Follow us to dive into Chinese art and culture and find out the latest information for visitors.

Motherâ€™s Day is just around the corner. Are you looking for the perfect way to make your mum feel special? If you are stuck for ideas, you might find inspiration in the images on the object shown below. How about bringing her a bouquet of her favourite flowers or treating her to some delicacies? Of course, inviting her for an enjoyable day out at the Hong Kong Palace Museum is also an ideal itinerary for this special day!

Wishing you all a happy Motherâ€™s Day!
Tickets are now available at hkpm.org.hk/en

å±•æœŸç”±2022å¹´11æœˆ9æ—¥è‡³2023å¹´2æœˆ20æ—¥ï¼ŒæŠŠæ¡æ©Ÿæœƒæ¬£è³åˆ—æ”¯æ•¦å£«ç™»ç‹å®¤å››ç™¾å¤šå¹´è—è¡“æ”¶è—ç²¾ç²¹ã€‚é–€ç¥¨ç¾æ­£ç™¼å”®ï¼Œç«‹å³è³¼ç¥¨ï¼šhkpm.org.hk/tc

One of the most important private art collections in the world, the Princely Collections of Liechtenstein will make their debut show in Hong Kong in a new special exhibition, â€œOdysseys of Art: Masterpieces Collected by the Princes of Liechtensteinâ€, featuring an impressive set of works that will transport you through centuries of European art history.

Divided into eight sections, this exhibition showcases over 120 priceless treasures from the Collections. Starting from the family palace, the exhibition revisits the collecting history of the family with five of the reigning princes of Liechtenstein. Among the Collectionsâ€™ crown jewels are the works by two distinguished Baroque painters, Peter Paul Rubens and Anthony van Dyck. A total of 36 major works, including "Mars and Rhea Silvia" and the "Portrait of Maria de Tassis", will be presented at the exhibition, making it the largest assemblage of such masterpieces in Hong Kong.

The exhibition will also introduce the architecture of the princely gardens and landscapes, examining the influence of Chinese art culture on European architecture, as well as the conservation and restoration efforts of the artworks by the Princely Collections. 

The special exhibition runs between 9 November 2022 and 20 February 2023. Seize this opportunity to view the priceless treasures of the Princely House of Liechtenstein spanning over four centuries. Tickets are now available at hkpm.org.hk/en

ä½ çš„æ”¢ç›’æ”¾äº†ç”šéº¼é›¶é£Ÿå’Œç³–æœï¼Ÿç•™è¨€èˆ‡æˆ‘å€‘åˆ†äº«ï¼Œé½Šé½Šå¤§é£½ã€Œå£ç¦ã€ï¼Œéå€‹è‚¥å¹´ï¼

Itâ€™s time to celebrate Chinese New Year! A â€œchuen hupâ€ (candy box) full of lucky snacks is one of the most common features of every household, a symbol that invites fortune and prosperity into the coming year.

â€œChuen hupâ€ used to be called â€œzan hupâ€, which means â€œcoming togetherâ€ or â€œtogethernessâ€. The multiple interior segments inside this â€œBox with bats, lotus scrolls and Eight Buddhist Treasuresâ€ were usually used to store sweets, fruits, various types of meat, five pungent spices, or other food. The Eight Buddhist Treasures on the lid are auspicious symbols. In the interior are eight fan-shaped containers surrounding one central circular container. The sky-blue glaze is visibly darker than other similar boxes made in the Qing court.

What have you packed in your candy box? Tell us in the comments below and letâ€™s dip into some treats!

Co-organised by the Hong Kong Palace Museum, the Sanxingdui Museum in Guanghan, and the Jinsha Site Museum in Chengdu and supported by the Sichuan Provincial Institute of Cultural Relics and Archaeology and the Chengdu Institute of Cultural Relics and Archaeology, and solely sponsored by Bank of China (Hong Kong), the special exhibition, â€œGazing at the Sanxingdui â€“ New Discoveries of Archaeology in Sichuanâ€, will be open to the public on 27 September. 

Priceless artefacts from the Sanxingdui Museum in Guanghan and Jinsha Site Museum in Chengdu have arrived at HKPM. Curators and conservators from Sichuan and HKPM are working closely together to perform condition checks before the installation of the treasures in Gallery 8.
 
The first four precious cultural relics to be unveiled at the HKPM include the following, all dating back 1300â€”1100 BCE:

â€¢ Stand of Tree No.2: a grade-one national treasure, the only bronze tree artefact in this exhibition

â€¢ Hybrid Tiger-Dragon Figure: unearthed between 2020 and 2022, one of the tallest animal-shaped figures excavated at Sanxingdui

â€¢ Gold Mask: unearthed between 2020 and 2022, the largest gold mask unearthed from Sanxingdui

â€¢ Grand Mythical Creature: unearthed between 2020 and 2022, the largest bronze figure excavated at Sanxingdui
 
The team are busy preparing to showcase approximately 120 extraordinary treasures for this Special Exhibition, which will be on view from 27 September to 8 January. September and October tickets are now available at hkpm.org.hk/en

The â€œCartier and Womenâ€ Special Exhibition debuts next Friday (14 April)! This exhibition explores the unique role and influence of women throughout Cartierâ€™s history. One of the thematic sections features the collections of renowned female icons including actresses Brigitte Lin and Carina Lau, and businesswoman Pansy Ho.  Come and view their tiaras and other precious pieces while uncovering intriguing stories between women and jewellery! 

The Special Exhibition runs from 14 April through 14 August. Tickets are now available on hkpm.org.hk/en

Learn more via https://cartierandwomen.hk/

ã€#HKPMArtefectsã€‘The significance of nail protectors in Qing fashion 

Nowadays, nail art is a common beauty routine. But did you know that noblewomen in the Qing dynasty also grew their nails long, and even wore nail protector accessories? Made from gilded silver, this pair of 'Fingernail guards' was crafted using a filigree technique, and decorated with a traditional bat pattern and the character for â€˜longevityâ€™, along with inlaid gems and pearls. 

In ancient China, long and slender fingers were considered desirable. Since women with longer nails were usually not required to work, long nails came to indicate oneâ€™s social status as well. Fingernail guards not only prevented damage to the nails, but also made the fingers look slim. The accessory was very popular among noblewomen at the time. 

In addition to fingernail guards, the clothes that women wore inside the Forbidden City really mattered, as did the other accessories they used. The difference in the materials and patterns of these clothes and accessories reflected the womenâ€™s social status, and acted as a kind of proof of identity. 

The Hong Kong Palace Museum exhibits a selection of accessories used by Chinese aristocrats. Stay tuned for more fun facts about Qing dynasty fashion!
